question: What are the potential consequences of pausing student visa interviews and expanding social media vetting for national security, university finances, and prospective international students?

content.source_1:
It‚Äôs the latest salvo against universities, many of whom rely heavily on foreign students for funds.

The Harvard University logo is displayed on a building at the school, April 15, 2025, in Cambridge, Massachusetts. | Charles Krupa/AP

The Trump administration is weighing requiring all foreign students applying to study in the United States to undergo social media vetting ‚Äî a significant expansion of previous such efforts, according to a cable obtained by POLITICO.

In preparation for such required vetting, the administration is ordering U.S. Embassies and consular sections to pause scheduling new interviews for such student visa applicants, according to the cable, dated Tuesday and signed by Secretary of State Marco Rubio.

If the administration carries out the plan, it could severely slow down student visa processing. It also could hurt many universities who rely heavily on foreign students to boost their financial coffers.

‚ÄúEffective immediately, in preparation for an expansion of required social media screening and vetting, consular sections should not add any additional student or exchange visitor (F, M, and J) visa appointment capacity until further guidance is issued septel, which we anticipate in the coming days,‚Äù the cable states. (‚ÄúSeptel‚Äù is State Department shorthand for ‚Äúseparate telegram.‚Äù)

The administration had earlier imposed some social media screening requirements, but those were largely aimed at returning students who may have participated in protests against Israel‚Äôs actions in Gaza.

The cable doesn‚Äôt directly spell out what the future social media vetting would screen for, but it alludes to executive orders that are aimed at keeping out terrorists and battling antisemitism.

Many State Department officials have complained privately for months that past guidance ‚Äî for, say, vetting students who may have participated in campus protests ‚Äî has been vague. It‚Äôs unclear, for example, whether posting photos of a Palestinian flag on an X account could force a student to undergo additional scrutiny.

The administration has used a variety of rules to target universities, especially elite ones such as Harvard, that it sees as too liberal and accuses of allowing antisemitism to flourish on their campuses. At the same time, it is carrying out immigration crackdowns that have swept up a number of students.

Spokespeople for the State Department did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

The news was met with frustration in much of the higher education community.

NAFSA: Association of International Educators, a group that advocates for foreign students, decried the decision. The group‚Äôs CEO, Fanta Aw, said it unfairly cast aspersions on hardworking students.

‚ÄúThe idea that the embassies have the time, the capacity and taxpayer dollars are being spent this way is very problematic,‚Äù Aw said. ‚ÄúInternational students are not a threat to this country. If anything, they‚Äôre an incredible asset to this country.‚Äù

Meta, which owns Facebook, WhatsApp and Instagram, declined to comment. Spokespeople for other platforms, including Google, Snap, X, TikTok, Discord, Bluesky and Reddit, also did not respond to questions about the policy.

The Trump administration has ordered a freeze on all newstudent visa interviewsat U.S. embassies and consulates, as it weighs a plan to require foreign applicants to undergo social media vetting, officials told the Associated Press.

The cable, dated Tuesday and signed by Secretary of StateMarco Rubio, outlines the forthcoming shift in vetting procedures. The Trump administration is also considering a policy that would require all foreign students applying to study in the United States toundergo social media screening.

"We have said before: the students are not a threat and the way this is framed within a national security lens, as if students are a threat when we know that students make up no more than 6 percent of total enrollment in the United States," Fanta Aw, executive director and CEO of NAFSA, Association of International Educators, toldNewsweek.

Newsweekhas reached out to the State Department and theDepartment of Homeland Security(DHS) via email for comment.

Pausing the visa category, which saw over 400,000 issuances in fiscal year 2024, would mark a shift inthe Trump administration's effortsto limit immigration, dramatically slow down the process for international students, and potentially cut off more funding to institutions that welcome them.

"Effective immediately, in preparation for an expansion of required social media screening and vetting, consular sections should not add any additional student or exchange visitor (F, M, and J) visa appointment capacity until further guidance is issued septel, which we anticipate in the coming days," the State Department cable states. Septel is shorthand for "separate telegram."

The U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Service (USCIS) began planning increased screening of immigrants' social media accounts in early March, stating that it would increase national security.

People applying for permanent residency (green cards) or citizenship from within the U.S. were already required to provide social media account information, but expanding the program to those planning to immigrate to the U.S. was aimed at around 2.5 million yearly immigrants.

The State Department's involvement in the process occurs at the embassy or consular level, where its staff determines eligibility for visas during interviews.

Pauses like the one reported Tuesday are not uncommon when the department is rolling out new policies, but this would come after months of focus by the administration on international students.

The State and Homeland Security departments have revoked or attempted to revoke student visas from those already studying at American schools.

Much of the focus has been on those allegedly linked to pro-Palestinian protests on campuses over the past year, with Rubio arguing that some actions and words were pro-Hamas, and therefore against U.S. foreign policy.

Last week, the administration announced it would revoke Harvard's ability to accept international students, a move that was quickly challenged and subsequently paused in the courts. PresidentDonald Trumplatercalled for a list of all foreign studentsat the school, saying many of their home countries paid nothing toward their education in the U.S.

Asked about the suspension at a briefing Tuesday, State Department spokesperson Tammy Bruce said the U.S. uses every available resource to vet people applying for visas:"We will continue to use every tool we can to assess who it is that's coming here, whether they are students or otherwise."

Fanta Aw, executive director and CEO of NAFSA, Association of International Educators, toldNewsweek:"We will be askingCongressto demand transparency from this administration, to step forward in letting the administration know the potential consequences that this will have for the fall semester and for the foreseeable future for students who have been wanting to come to the United States."

Aaron Reichlin-Melnick, senior fellow at the American Immigration Council, on X (formerly Twitter):"Trump's decision to suspend student visa interviews threatens nearly $44 billion in economic contributions and over 370,000 jobs across the United States, according to NAFSA. If the United States stops taking foreign students, the economic impact would be catastrophic."

Secretary of Homeland Security Kristi Noem, in a statement about Harvard last week:"It is a privilege, not a right, for universities to enroll foreign students and benefit from their higher tuition payments to help pad their multibillion-dollar endowments."

A U.S. official told AP Tuesday the suspension is meant to be temporary and will not affect applicants who already have scheduled visa interviews. The official spoke on condition of anonymity to discuss a confidential administration document.

A prolonged pause in student visa scheduling could cause delays that disrupt the enrollment plans of college, boarding school, and exchange students for the summer and fall terms.

A decline in international student enrollment may also strain university budgets. Many institutions have relied on full-tuition-paying international students to offset reductions in federal research funding.

Secretary of State Marco Rubio ordered US embassies and consulates on Tuesday to pause any student visa applicant interviews, according toan internal cable obtained by Politico.

‚ÄúEffective immediately, in preparation for an expansion of required social media screening and vetting, consular sections should not add any additional student or exchange¬†visitor ‚Ä¶ visa¬†appointment capacity until further guidance is issued [separate telegram], which we anticipate in the coming days,‚Äù the cable read.

Both theState DepartmentandDepartment of Homeland Securityhave moved to strip thousands of visas from foreign students in recent weeks with mixed success.

‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt speak about individual visa cases,‚Äù State Department spokeswoman Tammy Bruce told reporters.

‚ÄúWe take very seriously the process of vetting who it is that comes into the country. And we‚Äôre going to continue to do that ‚Ä¶¬† and again, whether they be student[s] or if you‚Äôre a tourist who needs a visa, or whoever you are, we‚Äôre going to be looking at you,‚Äù she added.

‚ÄúIt seems to be such a controversial thing that‚Äôs going on, but it shouldn‚Äôt be, and every nation should take seriously, and does, who‚Äôs coming in. So if you‚Äôre going to be applying for a visa, follow the normal process, the normal steps, expect to be looked at and and we go on from there.‚Äù

Last week, Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem moved to kick out nearly 7,000 Harvard University students from foreign countries ‚Äî but was blocked by a federal judge.

Oakland, Calif. US District Judge Jeffrey S. White implemented a nationwide injunction barring the Trump administration from terminating the legal status of any international students or allowing immigration authorities to arrest or detain them.

At least 4,000 visashave already been revoked from international students with rap sheets ‚Äî with charges including arson, wildlife and human trafficking, child endangerment, domestic abuse, DUI and robbery, a senior State Department official¬†told The Post last month.

The department previously set up an artificial intelligence-powered pilot program to ‚Äúcatch and revoke‚Äù student visas after scrubbing holders‚Äô social media accounts for statements expressing sympathy with Hamas or other terror groups, according to Axios.

‚ÄúThose who support designated terrorist organizations, including Hamas, threaten our national security,‚Äù Rubio said. ‚ÄúThe United States has zero tolerance for foreign visitors who support terrorists.‚Äù

US Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) announced in early April it was also taking into account an applicant‚Äôs support for ‚Äúantisemitic terrorism‚Äù when deciding whether to reject student visas or green cards.

Mahmoud Khalil was one of the first students whose role in anti-Israel demonstrations at Columbia Universitygot his visa and green card canceledin March.

The Trump administration has since been challenged in both immigration and federal courts over claims it had the right to deport Khalil, who served as a spokesman for anti-Israel groups including Columbia University Apartheid Divest.

Devin Connolly, managing partner at Reeves Immigration Law Group ‚Äî which is handling some cases of foreign students with revoked visas ‚Äî said reviews of social media accounts aren‚Äôt new and have most often been used by authorities to determine whether a marriage is legitimate.

‚ÄúThe administration, and especially Secretary Rubio, has been very clear that nobody is entitled to a visa and that they will not be issuing visas to foreign nationals whose beliefs and activities are contrary to the United States‚Äô national interests,‚Äù Connolly said.

‚ÄúHowever, to what extent will social media postings that are critical of the Trump administration and its policies be considered to be in conflict with our national interests?‚Äù he asked.

‚ÄúIt is easy to foresee denials for certain postings about Israel and Hamas, but whatabout postings about Afrikaners being granted refugee status? We will have to see if a subject like that is controversial enough to warrant a denial.‚Äù

The White House and State Department did not immediately respond to The Post‚Äôs requests for comment Tuesday.
